title: How to Dye Polyester with Dylon

steps.title: Make sure the fabric is no more than 50% synthetic.
steps.content: Make sure the fabric is no more than 50% synthetic. Dylon dye will not be effective on 100% polyester items , but blends of natural fibers and polyester can be dyed. Dylon recommends not dyeing any fabric that is made with more than 50 percent synthetic fibers. [1] X Research source Common natural fibers include cotton, linen, viscose, and denim. Common synthetic fibers include Gore-Tex, lycra, nylon, polyester, and spandex.

steps.title: Pick a darker-colored dye to achieve your desired shade.
steps.content: Pick a darker-colored dye to achieve your desired shade. Since synthetic fibers will reject dye, only the natural fibers will be there to pick up the dye. The less natural fiber, the lighter and more diluted the shade. [2] X Research source Keep in mind that your dyed item will be lighter than the color displayed on the packet.

steps.title: Remember that the fabric’s original color will affect the end result.
steps.content: Remember that the fabric’s original color will affect the end result. For example, a yellow shirt dyed with blue dye will result in a green shade. Patterns may also be visible after you dye them. If you want your fabric to turn the color of your dye, make sure it’s white when you begin. [3] X Research source If your original item has bleach marks or stains, those areas may not be completely covered by the dye. If there’s bleach marks, you can try bleaching the entire item, but it will lose its original color.

steps.title: Use Dylon Pre-Dye to change fabric from one strong color to another.
steps.content: Use Dylon Pre-Dye to change fabric from one strong color to another. Pre-dye helps lighten dark fabrics so it’s easier to change their color. Pour the contents of the packet into your washing machine, add the items, and run the longest and hottest cycle. Then add laundry detergent and wash the item as usual. [4] X Research source Dylon Pre-Dye is meant to be used in washing machines and not by hand. Run your washing machine for 1-2 empty cycles after using the pre-dye so it doesn’t affect your other clothes.

steps.title: Buy 1 machine dye pod for every 600 grams (21 oz) of fabric to be dyed.
steps.content: Buy 1 machine dye pod for every 600 grams (21 oz) of fabric to be dyed. The items should be dry when you weigh them. If your clothes weigh more than 600 grams (21 oz), you should split them into two or more batches. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wet the fabric before putting it and the dye pod in the washing machine.
steps.content: Wet the fabric before putting it and the dye pod in the washing machine. The items should be clean and damp so that they can accept the dye. Place the damp clothes in your washing machine and put an unwrapped and opened Dylon machine dye pod on top. [6] X Research source You can use the dye pod regardless of what type of washing machine you have.

steps.title: Use your washing machine’s regular wash cycle to dye your items.
steps.content: Use your washing machine’s regular wash cycle to dye your items. Set the machine to a full cycle with a water temperature of 40 °C (104 °F). Don’t use the economy or pre-wash options, because the water will not be the correct temperature or the cycle will be too long. [7] X Research source IF your washing machine doesn’t list exact temperatures, use the Warm cycle setting.

steps.title: Set the dye by running another cycle.
steps.content: Set the dye by running another cycle. This time, add laundry detergent to wash excess dye out of your items. [8] X Research source Use the same temperature water as you used for your other cycle. Once the cycle has finished, remove the items and run an empty cycle with laundry detergent to clean your machine. [9] X Research source If you don’t clean your washing machine, subsequent loads of laundry could become stained with excess dye.

steps.title: Dry the fabric on a drying rack.
steps.content: Dry the fabric on a drying rack. If you are air drying the fabric, keep it out of direct sunlight and make sure any folds have been shaken out. This will prevent fading or uneven spots of color. [10] X Research source After the first time, you can dry your items as you normally would.

steps.title: Wash the dyed items separate from your other laundry to keep them vibrant.
steps.content: Wash the dyed items separate from your other laundry to keep them vibrant. For the first few washes, keep your dyed items separate from the rest of your laundry to prevent fading. Use cool or warm water during your cycle. Washing your dyed items separately will also protect your other clothing from being stained with excess dye. [11] X Research source You can iron your dyed items as you normally would.

steps.title: Wash your item thoroughly and leave it damp.
steps.content: Wash your item thoroughly and leave it damp. The fabric needs to be clean so that it will accept the dye evenly. It needs to be wet for the dye to work. [12] X Research source Hand dyeing is best for small items like shorts, vests, or socks and for delicate items that you don’t want to put in the washing machine.

steps.title: Set up the dye bath with dye, water, and salt.
steps.content: Set up the dye bath with dye, water, and salt. Dissolve the entire package of dye in 500 millilitres (17 fl oz) of warm water. Fill a bowl or stainless steel sink with about 6 litres (6.3 US qt) of 40 °C (104 °F) water, stir in 250 grams (8.8 oz) of table salt, and then stir in the dye mixture. [13] X Research source Wear rubber gloves while mixing the dye since it could stain your skin. Some plastic and porcelain containers may get stained if you use dye in them.

steps.title: Submerge the fabric in the dye bath and stir for 60 minutes.
steps.content: Submerge the fabric in the dye bath and stir for 60 minutes. Stir the fabric continuously for 15 minutes with your gloved hand, and then stir periodically for 45 minutes. This evenly distributes the dye into the fabric. [14] X Research source Instead of your hands, you can also use a stainless steel spoon for stirring your fabric.

steps.title: Rinse the fabric in cold water, hand wash, and air dry.
steps.content: Rinse the fabric in cold water, hand wash, and air dry. You should keep rinsing until the water runs clear. Use warm water to wash the item. Dry the item on a drying rack away from direct heat and sunlight. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Wash your dyed fabric separately to avoid color bleed.
steps.content: Wash your dyed fabric separately to avoid color bleed. The first few times you wash your item, hand wash it in warm water separate from other items to prevent fading. This will also keep other delicate items from becoming stained with any runoff dye. [16] X Research source
